description:
'''Mbalax''' (or '''mbalakh''') is the urban dance music of [[Senegal]], [[Mauritania]] and [[the Gambia]]. The musical style is rooted in the indigenous instrumental and vocal styles accompanied by [[Polyrhythm|polyrhythmic]] sabar drumming of the [[Wolof people|Wolof]], a social identity that includes both the original Wolof people of the Greater [[Senegambia]] region and the urban panethnic identity that arose during [[colonialism]]. 

In the 1970s, mbalax arose as Senegalese fused indigenous music styles with urban dance music from the African diaspora, the West, and the continent.  These foreign sounds included U.S. [[soul music|soul]], jazz, and salsa. Afro Cuban musics from the diaspora, Congolese rumba, and [[rock music|rock]] were also fused with the rhythms of ''[[sabar]] t''hat were now played on the electric bass, guitar and keyboards.
